content:
y 13, 2016
												While I've always been in love with Jedi Knight; Jedi Outcast 2, I have my issues with it's sequel, Jedi Academy. Do I think the game is good, however? Well, it does say "Recommended", right? However, as I usually do, I will keep the bad stuff of the game ahead.First and foremost, while the game doesn't have as many as the previous game, it still has a few graphical errors with modern games. Mainly resolutions being 4:3, but those are fixed quite easily.What is probably the biggest problem, however, ain't the graphics but the direction the game takes. Remember the enthralling storyline the previous game had? Not here. In here instead, Kyle becomes a secondary character, and instead you create your own character, which sounds great on paper... But falls flat, as you're only given the choice of your combat style, being male or female, your outfit and race, and later on the game, what ending you want. You can also choose what missions to do, but that's kinda pointless as you have to clear at least 4 of the 5 given missions to advance the game.And that's another thing, the missions themselves are... Well, dissapointing compared to the previous game. Jedi Academy goes more for an "arcade" style, with items arround it and quantity of enemies over quality. Not until later in the game you're given a proper challenge, and even then half the enemies will be easy to kill by pushing them down a cliff and similar stuff. It also doesn't help at all that the game is WAY more short than the previous.It's third problem, is a character itself. Rosh. At the first minute of your playthrough you meet this guy, and even since then you will most likely hate him already. He's a piece of ♥♥♥♥, a worthless meatbag, and a bad character overall. And the hilarious part is that the writers of the game probably knew it, and  give you the option to kill him near the end, unlocking the Sith ending.The last issue this game has, is that weapons are irrelevant. From the start of the game you'll have your light-saber, and you'll BARELY use anything else, which is a shame, as the game still has it's great FPS action there from the previous game. It does force you to use them in one of the missions, and there is a new cool weapon, but that's it.All that aside, however, what do we have left? An enjoyable game were you get to feel like a motherf#cking Badass Jedi. Likely because of the incompetent enemies, but a Badass never the less. Light-saber combat is not only great, but it beats the previous game. Not only there are a few new moves, but there are also 2 new styles of combat: using two light-sabers at the same time, or using a dual-blade saber. There are also some sort of special attacks that can be used when hitting Mouse 1 and Mouse 2 at the same time, which consumes half your Force bar, but deal insane damage. About force powers, they're still there. Some have changed whoever, some have been erased, and some others have been added. The game does f#ck it when it gives you the choice of getting them at the order you desire, as they can make the game EXTREMELY EASY early on (such as the Lightning force power at LVL3, which nearly instantly kills most enemies of the early game, and deals high damage to enemy jedis, even pushing them back). Later in the game you'll have to get used to them to advance, and they can also be used to find cool secret areas, although there are not nearly as many as in the previous game.The multiplayer is also back in action, having more content and active players than the previous game, mainly because it has nearly all the crap it had before, but with some new aditions. Tons of models to choose for yourself (also having the option of making a custom one for yourself, like in the singleplayer game), and tons of maps and gamemodes as well.The game is also easily modabble, for the people out there who want to add crazy ♥♥♥♥ to the game, but that's up to you. It does help, however, to add better animations, textures and such.Is the game good? Yes. You'll have fun. However, if you're looking for a singleplayer experience, go play Jedi Knight; Jedi Outcast 2, as it delivers WAAAAAAAAAAY better than Jedi Academy. If you're looking for multiplayer action or mods, then this one's for you, and it's a solid purchase on a sale.And for the love of f#ck, kill Rosh.

number of helpful: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
2015
												I still believe this game is the best Star Wars Jedi/Saber Fighting game out there, even 12 years after its release.  The combat system (especially the saber-fighting) employed in this game is inexplicably unmatched in any Star Wars game released since this one.  I have played this game for many years off and on and I have only recently purchased it on Steam.  If you are a Star Wars fan and enjoy shooter games, this title will be an instant favorite for you especially if you can forgive the dated graphics.The single-player story is only so-so, as some of the characters and dialogue are weak at times (much like the movies) and the story-mode itself is not very long or infinitely replayable.  However, this game really shines in the multi-player mode with plenty of active servers, a very helpful community and a large collection of amazing custom content that greatly enhances the game.  You can get custom skins and maps with characters/locations from the Star Wars Universe if you want to play as one of your favorite characters.  Saber-dueling is the primary interest of the online community with some other communities focusing on full-force combat, gun combat and even role-playing.  There are also a collection of mods that help improve the MP experience like JA+, Movie Battles II, Lugormod and more!  Even in 2015, this is still one of the greatest Star Wars games ever made and is truly the closest you will get to fighting like a Jedi in a video game.  If you prefer RPG games you would probably like KOTOR or KOTOR II more and if you enjoy Battlefield, Counter Strike or CoD then Battlefront and Battlefront II might be more your cup of tea.  Still, I highly urge you to check out this title; new players are what keep this game alive despite the good amount of long-time active communities that are still around.  TL;DR Buy this game if you want to be a Jedi!  :D

												Say what you will about this game, I, personally, did not enjoy it. If you like chaotic hack and slash gameplay where you never completely feel in control of your character, you will like it, but to me, the gameplay felt like Goat Simulator with lightsabers. When I play a combat game, I expect to feel in control of the character I am playing in all aspects. In this game, however, it is quite the contrary. Every single action feels, for lack of better words, loose and slippery. Almost anything related to the force only seems to work 50% of the time on a good day due to finicky timing windows and accuracy quirks, and fighting against other lightsaber-weilding opponents almost feels like.... words cannot even describe how floppy it feels, how random and chaotic it feels in the WORST POSSIBLE WAY. At least to me. This is all my opinion, so take what you will from it.

ber 7, 2016
												I loved this game long ago; the singleplayer is as novel and interesting as everyone attests and the vanilla muliplayer is great couch-versus fun. With the mod MovieBattlesII, it is now essentially the best Battlefront-esque game you can play with a small and fairly active group of veterans and casuals to test your mettle against.The mod overhauls the vanilla saber combat into a really deep and intuitive new system which is unforgiving to newbies but very satisfying to learn the secrets and techniques. The extended duels always make me feel like I'm in an actual lightsaber battle, even when I lose my head (literally!).Each side also has 6(!!!) other classes with guns, including jetpack-equipped Mandolorians and Droidekas. But sabers is why I still play.Give it a go, it hasn't disappointed in 13 years.

content:
, 2015
PROS:+ decent story+ fun gameplay+ satisfying lightsaber combat+ cool missions+ creating your own character+ being a Jedi (or Sith)+ two endings+ great modsCONS:- graphic & resolution options are outdated- story is less driven and lacks a bit of focus- much less need of shooting compared to previous Jedi Knight games- level design could be betterComment:The Jedi Knight series moves onto this part where you no longer play as Kyle Katarn but get to create your own character. The game is much more lightsaber oriented as is shown by giving you one right at the beginning. And that is what the game excels at - lightsaber combat. Oh, and how much fun it is! With the dismemberment option on it feels like really having a powerful weapon you can cut every opponent with. On top of that you of course get Force powers. The story is not bad but lacks focus because you play as an unknown character without any background. Instead of looking over some plot events it instead rotates around your decisions to either become a Jedi or a Sith. This also effects the level design a bit. However it remains fun and enjoyable. Noteworthy are also two other things - multiplayer and mods. The community of players who play online is still strong and even some mods have a big following of players. The mods especially use most of the potential. like when some mods are letting you play ALL Star Wars lightsaber duels (movie ones and also others). This is definitely a game for anyone who likes Star Wars and lightsaber combat. Recommended!

content:
10, 2015
												Star Wars fan or otherwise, the Jedi Knight series (JKII:Outcast and JK:JAcademy) has one of (if not decisively) the best swordfighting mechanics to date, on par with the likes of Rune and Severance. For this alone, they are worth playing. Single player acts as a fun introduction to gameplay and provides all the tools needed (at a good pace) for moving on to the engaging multiplayer, which is truly where the game shines.If you get bored with the default game (unlikely), then it's most popular modification, 'Movie Battles II' kicks it up a notch in a class based siege style gameplay true to the movies. Different features, equally competitive and satisfying.If you want more acrobatic swordplay and are tired of the alternative's (Chivalry:Medieval Warfare / War of the Vikings) equally solid but slower pace, this is the one to try.

er 26, 2013
												I love how they did lightsaber combat! I wish there was more of it, or if someone made a samurai game that uses the same engine. I love being able to select my own combat style, and switching styles to adapt to my enemies. After some of the duels I find myself saying "that was freaking AWESOME!" They did a good job of making the lightsaber the #1 weapon, smart job of setting it apart from the first one where a lot of the game is played with blasters. I think the levels are designed pretty well to highlight force powers. On the negative side It's a little short, doesn't offer a whole lot of replay value, it's not like an RPG where you can play it twice and see entirely different content. There is some divergence depending on the path you take, but not much. I am satisfied with it though! It's an action game not an RPG

content:
26, 2015
												Jedi Academy is the latest and greatest (2003) of the Kyle Katarn/Dark Forces Star Wars series and the only one that I was able to play recently, due to the older games’ incompatibility with more modern Windows versions. I was unfortunately unable to get the game to run at higher resolutions than the default 800 x 600, but since I’ve played the game before, I was able to go through pretty fast and just ignore the poor graphics. The game is more than a decade old after all.The game’s story follows a new Jedi recruit named Jaden as he tries to work his way up to Jedi knight status. He has to hit the ground running though, since his very first day arriving at the academy there’s an attack by a mysterious Sith cult called the Disciples of Ragnos. This cult of dark force users is led by Tavion, one of the minor villains from a previous Jedi Knight game, who has now acquired some ancient Sith tech and is able to power up herself and her followers with it. With some help from your master Kyle Katarn, you have to stop Tavion and her followers from their grand plan of resurrecting a long dead Sith lord. Like the preceding Dark Forces Jedi Knight games, Jedi Academy is a first person shooter except when you pop out your lightsabre, then it switches to a third person perspective. Honestly though, you should probably have your lightsabre out all the time, so really it’s a third person sword game where you can use guns if you want. Right from the start you have a few force powers to choose from, such as push, pull, speed, and sight. These powers improve naturally as you go through the game and you can also choose between light/dark powers such as heal, lightning, protect, etc. I’ve played through the game about half a dozen times and I almost always get the same powers (heal, lightning, dark rage). They’re just too good to skip. You won’t be able to max all of the available skills, but you do have some room to experiment.The guns in the game, while good, just can’t match the effectiveness of a lightsabre. The lightsabre not only kills most enemies in one hit, it also deflects enemy lasers. As you progress, your ability to deflect/reflect enemy shots improves, and by the end you probably won’t be taking much damage from stormtroopers. The true obstacles in your path will be the cultist warriors who use lightsabres and force powers of their own. Lightsabre combat is a huge part of the game and if you suck at it, you’ll be stomped many times over. Fortunately (or not) there seems to be a tremendous element of luck when it comes to sword fighting, and if you swing wildly, there’s a good chance you’ll chop down the weaker enemies easily. Just remember that the game doesn’t autosave very often, so if you don’t manually save before sword fights, you might end up replaying large sections of the game. Remember how I said there was a lot of luck involved? Yeah, a weak enemy can slice you down in one shot very easily.Pros:+Right from the start you have force powers and a lightsabre, unlike the previous Dark Forces games I played. The sword fighting can make you feel like a badass with the slow-mo kills and katas (flashy sword moves) that you can use.+The story is intriguing and you get to try out a bunch of Star Wars weaponry. Most of them suck, but the concussion rifle is pretty cool. Watch out for the splash damage though, it’s huge. Remember though, that guns do not work on enemy force users. They either reflect the shot at you or just dodge it like Neo.Cons:-The game is very old, and with that comes poor graphics and incompatibility with Windows 7 & 8. You can get the game to run, but the screen resolution thing is very annoying. I tried everything from using compatibility mode to manually setting custom resolutions and restarting, but it just never changed.-It is possible to just run through most of the game not fighting anyone, especially in the last few levels. The vast majority of enemies will stop chasing you if you get more than one room away. This includes the more powerful cultist sword masters as well (the real threats). Also, if you’re looking for an overpowered force ability, the force lightning can get you through most of the game, clearing out entire rooms of baddies in one shot.Overall, the game is fun to play, and if you have it from the recent Star Wars bundle, this is probably the oldest game on there that I would still replay. The other Dark Forces/Jedi Knight games have aged poorly and may not be worth it, despite how good they were back in the day.

												This game was so good back in the days.Why am I saying '' back in the days ''?The multiplayer is pretty dead, I didn't really like the SP (except when using mods).The multiplayer was the good point of this game especially if you played with Movie Battles II.I wish there would be bots on MBII, it would be amazing to play on this mod with bots and maybe it could help the multiplayer to get back on.The campaign is awesome on a first run but after that, it gets boring which is why there is a multiplayer.The game runs on the great Id Tech 3 engine, the engine that was used for Quake 3 so what do you except?It's the best Star wars game when it comes to lightsaber duels.I'd suggest it to any Star Wars, FPS, TPS and science fiction fans.JA Multiplayer 9/10JA Single-Player 8.5/10

												This game is.. Ok. It has goods, and it has bads. The graphics and animations are not good, but that is to be expected from a game as old as it, so I will not say any more on the subject. The ability to use force powers and lightsabers are awesome, and executed really well, making it feel quite realistic. However, the story of the game is lacking, almost feeling a bit tacked on, and the play time is only about 10 hours per play. It has good replay value though, not the best, but I have played it over many times, just because the combat is so fun to use. This game is good, and I do reccomend it, if you enjoy shooting people with lightning and cutting people in half. 7/10

												Star war's jedi knight jedi academy is a sort of 3rd person dueling combat type game,If you play singleplayer it basicly goes like this.Make your char play a couple of mission's.Level up either lightside or darkside force powers that does affect luke and kyle talk to you about.If you max out a darkside force power they will say your future is clouded and be carefull!If you pick lightside they say You have a bright future you get a idea of what it is it take's a star wars game with very go here and never go anywhere else because this isn't a open world game type game,You have to go the same path over and over and over depending on if you play the game over again.The combat is good for a 2003 game it hold's up with many other game's that were at the time considered the best games of the year of course it doesn't have the AWESOME PS4/XBOX ONE/Awesome beast pc graphic's but for that time they were good.The Multiplayer part of the game is well done with a bunch of mode's to choose from such as duel,team ffa,FFaCapture the flag,Siege and more.But the best part about this game is the mods you can put into your game to add extra content or just silly stuff like let's say you install,A new model for your game you can play as that model and etc.Now i reccomend the Conversion mod MB2 which improves the combat alot.The base game is still a blast to play and you can have hours of fun playing this game.So i give Star war's jedi knight jedi academy a 7/10 it would be higher if you put mod's on it but that overall game is great on it's own and is repeatable without getting boring you can spend hours on end playing this game.

number of helpful: 6 of 9 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
ry 15, 2015
												A long time ago in a galaxy far, far away.... I played this gem. Jedi Knight: Jedi Academy is probably, by far, my most favorite Star Wars game. PS: Despite my gametime is only 3 odd hours or so, I've actually beaten this game multiple times in the past.. with my now abandoned Windows XP machine. Ha.This game offers two modes, single player where you progress through the storyline as Jaden or Multiplayer where you play against other players in Royal Rumble FFA or Capture the Flag (my favorite mode). This review emphasizes on SP side.In single player, you'll have to beat three chapters consisting five episodes each to the total of fifteen. And later you have to beat 'boss levels' after each chapter, so make it eighteen. Gametime as a whole for SP mode isn't that long, ten odd hours or less. But still, entertaining. Each episode has its own unique objective, ranging from rescue mission to dismantling bombs. The variety of environment design and levels also make it enjoyable to progress through this single player missions.Everytime you enter an episode, except boss levels, you'll have a chance to assign one Force Power to pick one among eight options, four Light Core and four Dark Cores. This makes things a bit more personal and customizable to suit your liking. You want to be the real Protector Jedi? Pick Light Cores. Or you want to be the real dark side? Get Rage and Lightning Force for all chaos you want! Do note that picking Cores doesn't affect the ending, despite Luke's review after each Act finished. The ending (good side or dark side) will be affected much later in the game by making a choice. I won't spoil that, though, here.Customization extends a bit more, where you can select from pre-made character designs and your lightsaber hilts / color. Much later in the game, you'll be allowed to construct more advanced lightsaber like Duals and Staff. And yeah, unlike in previous title Outcast, you'll have this lightsaber right off the bat in your arsenal. Only the Advanced Lightsabers that won't be available straight from the start.Control mappings admittedly are very nice. You'll have no issue assigning keyboard buttons to specific action e.g Jumping or Crouching. The  menu also can detect modern Keyboards/Mice weird buttons so you can assign the commands to those as well.Game mechanic is terrific and personally for me it's this game's strongest point. With Lightsaber available in many styles, you can have fun fighting your opponents - slashing right and left and launching Lightning attacks at them. All done in real time! There are few combos you can learn from in-game manuals so that you can have easier fights especially when playing on higher difficulty levels. I rarely trigger my guns, except when forced in one level - in that level your Lightsaber is confiscated so yeah....Graphic wise, the game's not aged well. In order to 'play' the game properly, you have to get some settings right. First, the tame has to be manually set up if you want to play on widescreens - pretty much modern LCDs. Lower textures are seen from the get-go everywhere - by today's standard, anyway.  There's a workaround for that, though. Mods for textures are also available to make it more bearable if you can't stand the original. Game also refuses to be minimized, making it silly if you love to alt-tab while playing like me. As it stands, there are game breaking bugs. I've personally encountered bugs where a door essential to progress refused to open (dismantling the bombs mission in a reactor). I restarted that mission from the scratch and hoped to progress, luckily I was able to after restart. Don't expect a patch for this.However, being an old game, you can expect your weak rig that can't run Evolve or some other high demanding games NOW launches this game with ease, with all graphic settings maxed. Game also is compatible with modern OS, much to my surprise. I am running this game well on Windows 7 x64 and 8.1 x64 without issues - other than issues from the game itself (game breaking bug I wrote above). I can't say about MAC version as I don't have MAC, or Linux if you want to WINE this.All in all, a very recommended game even for just Single Player if you can't stand Multiplayer.Old school score: 9.5/10

y 5, 2016
												After years of playing this game when I was younger, I could not find a game that itched that Star Wars scratch as good as this game. Honestly, I've played many good games, many so-called "Game[s] of the Year," but no game has really given me the satisfaction like this one does. Simply put - it is a masterpiece. That is why, after all these years, I was drawn back into it. More specifically, I was drawn back into the MBII modification for the game. It is superb, with an active and friendly community. A lot of people still play this and I've noticed that there has been some newcomers as well. This community deserves to grow. The game + MBII mod are too good to go unnoticed. Honestly, this game has aged well. The graphics are still good. And the availability of content, of FREE content is vast. This game deserves more publicity because honesty it puts all other games to shame. Buy it. Play it. Download MBII. Play MBII. Prosper.Welcome.

The story mode had interesting missions and you get to create your own character, (choose from six species available male/female) choose a lightsaber, and midway trough the game you'll be able to switch your saber to dual sabers or a two-handed saber like DarthMaul had. content:
9, 2016
												This game is a gem.  By today's standards a very old-fashioned gem, but underneath the crust of dated graphics is a diamond core.  The single-player campaign is enjoyable to play through even today and gives a solid introduction to multiplayer, which is where the game really shines.  The multiplayer community is not what it was but there are still servers which see activity.  There are also a whole bunch of mods available; everything from skins to partial to total conversions.  If you've ever really wanted a lightsaber and to be able to wield it like a Jedi, I recommend you grab this little piece of history.  SP will give you a taste, while in MP you have a shot at true mastery.  Some people have mad skills.  (I don't).

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
7, 2015
												I recommend Star Wars Jedi Knight: Jedi Acadamy. The combat is usually fun and being a psycho lunatic laser sword butcher is fun. It's always fun enough to keep playing, but there are some things holding the game back. I have some big reservations about this game. The voice acting was really terrible. It's the kind you'd expect from a cheap cartoon for ten year olds. The same goes for the plot.  At one point it is revealed the recruit who was obviously going to turn on the jedi from the moment he was introduced at the beginning of the game has in fact turned on the jedi. In his defense, though, the dark side did have two hot dark jedi chicks that liked to party. The Jedi Academy run by Luke just had some old coots nagging you to keep a good attitude while you're doing their work. Being a Star Wars title there's plenty of jibber jabber about sides of the force. I don't really see how the jedi can claim to be so morally superior when they kill everyone that stands in the way of their goals. It's just because they're not ♥♥♥♥♥♥ off or scared when they're doing it that keeps them from turning to the dark side of the force? There are a good solid 18 levels or so and took around 12 hours to finish game. While they do a reasonably good job of mixing of the objectives and scenery of the varied locations. It all really boils down to fighting most enemies with guns or dark jedi with a light saber and doing a lot of often crazy platform jumping. Towards the end of the game I was getting so tired of fighting light saber duels. I just stopped fighting them whenever possible  and kept running ahead until they stopped chasing me. It was a largely successful strategy for speeding up the game. The light saber fighting is maybe about as good as one can realistically expect. There are a couple of types of slashes and the light saber can be thrown like a boomerang. The fights seemed like they just came down to spamming the button until enough hits connect. When winning a duel the game will go into slow motion and you can see a cool shot of the fatal blow and bodies do get sliced up.  The worst part about them is that it's expected to use force powers during duels and it can be hard trying to move my characater and hitting the function keys at the same time. The best part, hands down, is using the force push to throw enemies off of cliffs. Hilarious every time.  As the game progresses the main character is completing his jedi training and he becomes more powerful as the game procedes. By the time the game is ending your character can jump five stories high and the light saber is almost heat-seaking.  You can also choose optional force powers to upgrade at the end of each level. So there are some very minor RPG elements to the game.The music in the game is just classic Star Wars soundtrack and it still sounds fantastic. The boss fights are really tough and time consuming. They deliver big damage quickly and so most of the time I'd spending running around avoiding them while I recharge my health and then engage them again for a minor skirmish before I run away again to heal up. The game isn't overly difficult. I did save a lot, though. Jedi Acadamy is fun, it just lacks that certain something should have taken it to the next level.

The game isn't overly difficult. I did save a lot, though. Jedi Acadamy is fun, it just lacks that certain something should have taken it to the next level.

er 28, 2016
One of the best games ever about one of the best film franchises ever. It completely captures the feeling of the original Star Wars trilogy that first blessed us in 1977.  It's got the magic, the cheesiness, the charm, the story, the characters, and the world of Star Wars. This game is incredibly underrated and a lot of people would play Knights Of The Old Republic if they were looking for a great Star Wars game. I love that game as much as the next guy, but i will say that this game has a much better combat system. Due to these examples. the game is near perfect. Now as good as this game is, it does have it's flaws. The voice acting is not very good, the graphics are incredibly outdated, and some of the animations are very stiff. However, since it came out in 2003, I'm willing to shrug it off. Overall, this game is definitely worth playing for any Star Wars fan, so I would give it a 9.2/10.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
y 24, 2015
												It's an old game, so any computer that was made 2007 or later should run it great. You'll need a few unoffical files to get it running, but afterwards, it's fine.For a dated game, you'll notice that the game doesn't have HD graphics or anything. But any Star Wars fan (such as myself) will tell you that these Jedi Knight games developed by Raven are, by far, the best Star Wars games out there. The lightsaber combat is engaging and you can run around with a single lightsaber with your choice of fighting style, use dual-wield lightsabers, or channel your inner Darth Maul and use a staff. There's a plethora of force powers to use, even the movie ones such as Jedi Mind Trick and Force Choke. While the multiplayer side is most likely dead, the singleplayer experience is fine on its own.But the best part is the modding community. Adding mods is almost as easy as downloading files from the Steam Workshop, and Star Wars fans are probably the most creative people out there. You can play as Darth Vader for your Sith needs, or give the game a comedic effect and saber people as Homer Simpson, Duffman, or even Bender. There is a singleplayer mod that allows you to romp around as Jack Sparrow. If you wish the game had more up-to-date graphics, somebody has created an HD texture overhaul, and there is also a Widescreen mod to make the game fit a 1920x1080 monitor properly.Overall, I give this game a 9/10. It's definitely a unique experience with or without mods and even if you aren't a fan of Star Wars, you can still have a great time with this game. If you love Star Wars, you'll love this. Oh, and grab the source code. What is in there is hilarious.

content:
ry 8, 2015
Excellent game.Ever wanted a star wars game where you can play as an FPS or third person hack and slash. Well look no further cause this is the game for you. Star wars Jedi knight: Jedi academy is the fourth game in the jedi knight series. The campaign sets you up as a student of the new jedi academy run by Master Luke Skywalker. You basically complete missions while also trying to figure out the motives of a mysterious sith cult. There are over 20 missions available.Gameplay involves intense combat, some platforming and puzzle solving. You start of with a light sabre and limited force powers. As you play, you will unlock new sabres, weapons and force powers. The lightsabre combat looks amazing, especially when you face the sith guys (really flashy). Other weapons include: Rifles, sniper, rockets, shotgun, grenades and pistol. Each weapon has a secondary fire mode such as scope, grnade launcher, charged shot, auomatic fire etc. You have limited ammunition available for guns and will need to restock via containers or looted from corpses. With each mission you complete you can select a new force power to level up/learn. You can only choose light and dark force powers to learn and upgrade, with the neutral powers upgrading naturally as you progress though the story. Besides the sith, you also face other foes such as stormies, jet troopers, thugs, rancor and wampas.The level design is amazing. Each mission you do, sets you in a unique place with different objectives available. The level of detail of the levels are great as there are plenty space to move around and secrets to find.The sound is also good. Besides the awesome star wars soundtrack that we are accustomed to from the movies, the voice acting in this game is good as well. Besides the single player campaign, there is also a multiplayer mode available. In multiplayer you and 15 other players face off in arenas. Everyone has lightsabres and a few guns. There are also bots available (up to 15) that you can play with should the multiplayer be dead (which unfortunately it is). You can choose a large variety of characters to play as/face off including stormies, boba fett, Luke etc. Furthermore, you can customise you lightsabre colour, hilt, fighting style (dual, single, attached sabres) as well as force powers. There are a variety of game modes including: deathmatch, team deathmatch and capture the flag. In the arenas, you can find power ups, health packs as well as new guns to play with.I highly recommend this game for fans or star wars or people who want good hack and slash game. Worth every cent.

content:
6, 2014
												The best Jedi game ever made. Better than the hack jobs of Force Unleashed and Force Unleased 2 by a wide margin. The lightsaber combat in this is actually tactical and requires a fair amount of skill to get good at. Later levels in the game even sport some skilled AI that can result in epic battles or instant kills if you're unlucky, un-skilled, or just not careful. Environments/Levels in this game are varied and dangerous for both you and your opponents as virtually anything in the game environment can be used to kill/maim/injure. Powers available to you through the Light and Dark side aren't restrictive and you can mix and match all you want until you hit the power cap (choose wisely!). The power creep in this game isn't overwhelmingly in your favor either, with a nice steady progression through the game as you unlock points to invest into powers of your choosing.Controls require some personal configuration and the management of them does get annoying. Combat controls are easy to grasp and the seamless transition from saber to blaster is nice.The game is even fully voice acted and has a solid story behind it that is actually pretty good.Character choices are neat, but nothing fancy. The same goes for lightsaber customization.

content:
, 2013
												Jedi academy uses the same engine and builds off the story of its predecessor.  However this time around you aren’t playing as Kyle Katarn but as Jaden Korr.  A both gender and species neutral name that allows for character customization.  Something that they took as a integral part of the creating of this game.  You can choose your species, gender, outfit, lightsaber hilt, and blade color.  And given the time period, this was a very new thing for a game like this.The story starts off great, and fully to what I would expect.  It was nice to be able to choose the missions performed and the order of them.  As well as being able to skip the last one and move the story on to the next plot point.  Of course doing so would effect your characters powers, since you are taking away the chance to level up a Force power.  Its a definite give and take, and I opted to take the short route more often then otherwise.While the story does start off strong, it quickly weakens, and all but falls to the floor.  The idea that a cult of dark Force users are draining the force energies from different locations across the galaxy.  It has so many holes its just ridiculous, and I haven’t even gotten into the details of it.  But the worst part of the story, is the blatant teenager fantasy.  Its a story that was written for angsty teenagers looking for something to connect to.  It also screams predictability from the first scripted sequence to the last.  You don’t need to be a, well anything, to figure out what’s going to happen next.There are some locations that felt like they were thrown into the game as a ‘Hey look, where you get to go!”.  And after I played and did a little research I discovered  that’s exactly why they added the location!  Tatooine, Hoth, and even a Rancor and Chewbacca are all there just so they can say they are there.  Taking a thing, and writing a story around it is never a good idea.  And here they have done it four times inside the main story arc.  They only thing that helps this is the way the missions are offered as single objectives that aren’t integral to the plot.Getting away from the story and focusing on some of the better aspects of the game, like the gameplay.  The lightsaber combat was acceptable at most.  Maybe its just me, but it was also laughable.  There is a move set you can work with, or you can be like me and and just click M1 like a manic and hope for the best.  Button combos have never been my strong point, with only succeeding at them with a handful of games.  And Jedi Knight: Jedi Academy was not one of them.  Sometimes in my rapid clicking I would preform some random move, surprising even myself, before going back to my standard slashing.I have a problem with games that use lightsabers, because they always weaken them.  A lightsaber doesn’t cut through anything like a hot knife through butter.  But it will do this with most things.  I can forgive a games engine not allowing me to cut the railings off of a scaffolding.  But one swing on a Stormtrooper should be all that’s needed to remove that Trooper as obstacle, one swing.  Unless it is wielding a lightsaber to block the attack or is armored with Cortosis, one hit.He called it a “laser sword”…  Seriously at one point there was a short scripted sequence where a thug or Stormtrooper or somebody used the phrase ‘laser sword’.  I about turned the game off there.The AI has its moments of udder fail.  Things like Stormies just standing there and shooting you as you walk right up to them and cut them down.  There are also mission where you are followed by a companion, and often times they show you just how much they love to fall into pits.  I swear Kyle spent more time at the bottom of a shaft than actually helping me.  All the while making comments about how hes ‘got this one’.  It just became a joke, and I had all but forgotten he was a part of the level.The game ends almost as predictably as it progressed, and just as predicted I didn’t really care.  I was just happy to be done with another game, and ready to move onto something else.  Not as well rounded a game as Jedi Outcast was, but better then the rest of the series.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
, 2016
												I am going to divide this review up by reviewing both Multiplayer and Singleplayer. Before I go furher, I have to say that Jedi Academy easily has the best lightsaber/sword fighting combat in a game (that I have played) to date. I will list pros and cons below:PROS:+Excellent combat (and super satisfying)+Force combat+Hundreds of combinations+Generally friendly community+Lightsaber customization (though limited)+Kyle's back!+Countless mods still being made (A Kylo Ren mod came out like a year ago, that is how dedicated fans are playing)CONS:-I should write this down but I can't summarize it in a phrases. When you get in the game, it will look a little odd. It is based of the Quake III engine and can have rather awkward cutscenes. The movements are not as fluid as other games either. Keep in mind though that Jedi Academy did come out around 10 years ago, or more. Going through the story, it does get a little out of the ordinary and the story is thrown in like, "Here it is. That is all." There is not much innovation from the last game, and the story is probably worst here than in Jedi Outcast. There are no surprises here besides a small one about halfway through the game. On top of that, the final boss is pretty lame. I ended the game thinking, "That's it? That was the boss?" The multiplayer is a lot of fun though. It borrows a lot of the movements from the predecessor Jedi Outcast, but adds the new lightsaber customization, so that not everyone has the same lightsaber. The powers are the same, I think they removed a few game modes like Jedi Master and I think Holocron FFA, and replaced those with Siege. I wish I could find a server that actively plays Siege though. It was a ton of fun years ago, but I think they all shut down because there were three maps for Siege. All in all, I highly reccomend this game to everyone that likes saber combat, unique missions, but does not really mind the story. It was a bit of a let down, but everything else is well worth it. 8.5/10

content:
er 24, 2014
												I'll start with the biggest strength: There is no better series/game for a free flowing lightsaber/force power action game, past or present. Battlefront and Force Unleashed were the closest in the Star Wars universe and others have tried in other universes with similar concepts but none of them touch the feel of this game in my opinion. I have played them all extensively and I still come back to this one when I really want to swing a saber and throw some fools off a ledge with Grip or Lightning. The movement and Force Powers all feel just right and the varied move sets based on saber stances/styles are endlessly adaptable to make for a unique fight every time - or you can find one trick you love and use it till your fingers grow arthritic.That brings me to the second strongest aspects: It was one of the first games to successfully implement environment running once you level up a bit (aka Jedi parkour). You can hop around, wall run, and just generally be a badass both in and out of fights. The missions are all in unique locations that capture the feel of the universe and provide unique experiences. The graphics and physics have held up well all things considered - at the time they were incredible. That isn't to say there aren't flaws, but nothing game breaking that I have found and generally lots of fun.The biggest weakness: The story line is a bit predictable but I honestly don't care one tiny bit. The general idea and delivery is good enough for me. If you are expecting something that will cause you to do some serious soul searching, this is probably not going to be the place to find it, but there are two endings for a bit of variety.Overall I would strongly recommend this game because it delivers on what it tries to deliver on - great gameplay in a fast paced lightsaber/force using environment with a million different ways to approach any fight.

content:
er 29, 2015
												Jedi Academy is the last game in the dark forces series, you play as Jaden, a student training at luke's jedi academy and go on many missions from fighting stormtroopers to cultists.Pros:- Extremely believable lightsaber physics with dismemberment and sparks that fly off your victims limbs- Satisfying combat and a range of weapons, you can go with an assortment or blasters and customize your lightsaber to duel wield, double-bladed, etc.- Solid graphics for the time that still look pretty decent today- fun multiplayer, there are mods and services like gameranger where you can host or join a serverCons:-The story is weak and disjointed basically you play random missions that are loosely connected to a dark jedi cult- the voice acting is also on the weak side and comes off as extremely cheesyVerdictJedi Academy is one of the most fun and enjoyable star wars games ever. You get your ightsaber from the start and have a decent amount of customization. The story is weak and is just there so you have a reason for doing what your doing, if you want a good story play jedi outcast. This is highly recommended.

content:
r 14, 2015
												Best Jedi simulator ever. You start out as a weak little padawan. You jump a little higher than normal, push one guy down, and three guys with blasters spread out across a room can stop you. By the end you are a jedi master! You can leap around building, throw whole squadrons of stormtroopers around the room, and run around without blasters being able to touch you. The progression is very noticeable is what I'm saying. Also, you basically act like a normal, non-Skywalker jedi would. You take on jobs from investigating rumors and guarding the ship to hunting down sith. Not feeling the lightsaber? (even though its the best weapon) You can use an arsenal of weapons that make all of the CoD guns feel the same. The levels do have some good variety for the time it was made. Like there is one where you get to race through a valley on a speeder bike while taking out enemies. Would love to see a modern sequel.

er 20, 2016
												HOLY ****Lightsaber combat is awesome and feels awesome to do backflips of someone and do a SICK combo.Guns are not underpowered and can use them instead of a lightsaber if thats what you want to do.You can choose what weapons you want to bring on a mission. Every mission you can upgrade one force ability be it light or dark. Many force abilites that feel awesome useful and fun to use.The levels , oh boy the levels are awesome. Every map and level feels 10x different and 10x better than the last one you just played with something new happening wheather it be story based or just ****ing epic You can customize your character to to 4 different races , male or female you can also choose their clothing and lightsaber colour and modelAs your progress in the story your lightsaber is upgraded to different fighting stances , dual sabers or double sided If there is a map you don't like then **** it you don't have to play it , in each chapter when it gives you the maps you have to complete to move on in the story you only have to complete 5 (out of the 6) maps.The ending has multiple ways to go (depending on what force abilites you picked) ( And what you do at the end) with 3-4 (i think) different endings.Mutiplayer.... Just as awesome as the story with different gamemodes that used to be big community If you really want to play multiplayer but no friends to play it with you can jump in a game with bots on ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ settings or KennyS settings.Star Wars :Jedi Knight - Jedi Academy Still holding on as one of my favourite gameThat i have so many good memories of playing this game when i was younger finshing the game after 10 hours and playing it again right away.I have atleast 1000+hours on this game on non steam version and plan to extend that further.Thank you and i hope you consider buying this awesome game.

content:
er 27, 2011
												Despite being relatively old, it's still my favourite Star Wars game. I've played many Star Wars games and none of them felt quite as right as this one. SW KOTOR was too RPG, SW TOR is too expensive, and the rest of the SW games feel either too arcade or standart FPS, but this one is the perfect fast-paced action adventure style SW. Lightsaber duels, character/force/lightsaber customisation, tons of mods and skins, classic MP modes {yes, people still play it}, rich campaign and more. The game features both FPS and TPS perspectives, you can adapt the game to your own play style, can use several lightsabers or weapons or both if you must, and every lightsaber technique has unique moves and combos. If you're looking for some fun enjoyable action game, go for the SW Jedi Academy.

content:
r 14, 2015
												Best Jedi simulator ever. You start out as a weak little padawan. You jump a little higher than normal, push one guy down, and three guys with blasters spread out across a room can stop you. By the end you are a jedi master! You can leap around building, throw whole squadrons of stormtroopers around the room, and run around without blasters being able to touch you. The progression is very noticeable is what I'm saying. Also, you basically act like a normal, non-Skywalker jedi would. You take on jobs from investigating rumors and guarding the ship to hunting down sith. Not feeling the lightsaber? (even though its the best weapon) You can use an arsenal of weapons that make all of the CoD guns feel the same. The levels do have some good variety for the time it was made. Like there is one where you get to race through a valley on a speeder bike while taking out enemies. Would love to see a modern sequel.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
6, 2016
												Mit "Jedi Academy" fand die altehrwürdige Jedi-Knight Reihe (leider) einen - hoffentlich nur vorläufigen - Abschluss. Dabei ist das Spiel kein offizieller dritter Teil sondern nur ein Ableger der Reihe. Was mit Dark Forces als eine Art "Star Wars Doom" begann, ging mit "Jedi Knight" und der Erweiterung "Mysteries of the Sith" weiter bis hin zu dem ebenfalls grandiosen "jedi Knight II - Jedi Outcast", welches 2002 zum Kinostart von Episode 2 erschien. Letzteres wurde von der Kritik hochgelobt, neben der tollen Grafik und Action war das Spiel auch atmosphärisch ausgezeichnet gelungen. Auch die original Synchronstimmen von Luke Skywalker und Lando Calrissian trugen das Ihre dazu bei. Ein Jahr später legten die Raven Studios dann mit Jedi Academy nach. Storytechnisch und grafisch macht das Spiel im Vergleich zum Vorgänger leider keine großen Fortschritte. Allerdings muss man bedenken, dass es nach wie vor auf der Quake III-Arena Engine von 1999 basiert. Die war eben auch 2002 schon veraltet, leiste abseits der etwas altbackenen Optik aber nach wie vor ausgezeichnete Arbeit. Die Schusswechsel und hohen Jedi-Sprünge gehen absolut intuitiv von der Hand. Da fühlt man sich tatsächlich etwas an Quake III erinnert. Was das Spiel aber von seinem großen Uhrahn abhebt, und gerade auch als Star Wars Spiel einzigartig macht, sind die grandiosen Lichschwertkämpfe. Diese laufen im Gegensatz zu den Schusswechseln standartmäßig in der Third-Person Ansicht ab und wirken - obwohl Teil des aktiven Gameplays - absolut perfekt szeneastisch Inszeniert. In modernen Actionspielen wäre das, was man hier "live" zu sehen bekommt, allenfalls als stupide Quick-Time-Events ins Spiel eingebunden - siehe The Force Unleashed. Lediglich in Spielen von Platinum Games wie Bayonetta oder Vanquish und mit Abstrichen vielleicht in DMC kann man heute noch derart intensive Nahkampf-Aktion aktiv erleben. Und die Lichtschwert Duelle sowie die Machtkräfte sind es, die sich im Vergleich zu "Jedi Outcast" wirklich verbessert haben. So wirkt der Machtblitz jetzt irgendwie wuchtiger, und ist auch grafisch weit schöner anzuschauen. Auch sind neue Kräfte hinzugekommen, wie der Machtentzug und die Rage. Mir scheinen irgendwie auch die Lichtschwertkämpfe noch intuitiver und flüssiger zu laufen - obwohl die in "Jedi Outcast" auch schon die absoluten Höhepunkte bildeten. Die Kämpfe enden in äußerst sehenswerten Finishing Moves, bei denen die Sith auch schon mal das ein oder andere Körperteil verlieren. Seine USK 16-Werung hat das Spiel somit verdient. Außerdem ist es jetzt möglich, sich im Laufe des Spiels ein Doppelschwert anzufertigen oder zwei Lichtschwerter auf einmal zu führen. Dies verändert die Lichtschwertkämpfe spürbar, und erhöht zusammen mit den verscheidenen Spezies, die als Hauptcharaktere zur Wahl stehen, den Wiederspielwert enorm. Außerdem kann man sich im Laufe des Spiels entscheiden, zur dunklen Seite zu wechseln, was aber nur die Story etwas abändert und wenig Auswirkungen auf das Gameplay hat. Die Story sehe ich tatsächlich als den größten Schwachpunkt des Spiels. Sie ist irgendwie sehr Standartmäßig gestrickt: Neuer Sithkult bedroht die neue Republik, neuer Jedi muss sich dem in den Weg stellen. Auch deshalb, weil die Missionen in verschiedenen Reihenfolgen gespielt werden können - was eigentlich eine super Idee ist - kommt kein richtiger Erzählfluss auf. Diese Mängel werden für mich aber durch das absolut geniale Gameplay, tolle Star-Wars Atmosphäre und das tolle Leveldesign mehr als Wettgemacht. Storymäßig macht es natürlich Sinn, mit Dark Forces anzufangen. Leider ist dies im deutschen Steam Store nicht mehr erhältlich, weil es in Deutschland lächerlicherweise auf dem Index ist, und sich keiner die Mühe macht, es von dort zu entfernen. Ein Schicksal, welches sein älterer Bruder Doom lange mit ihm teilte. Daher empfehle ich, mit dem ersten Jedi Knight einzusteigen.

content:
y 9, 2016
												This is the best Star Wars game I've played, other than KOTOR. (Although honestly I haven't played KOTOR II or any of the other Jedi Knight games.) •The combat system is the best I've seen in a Star Wars game. •The missions are fun and challenging, even on the regular difficulty. •The main game is long enough without being too long(unless you're as bad as I am). •There is a nice amount of character customization, but the species choices are a bit lacking. •The graphics still hold up well for a game that was made over a decade ago. •And there is still online multiplayer that is pretty fun.Now, for the bad stuff (which isn't a lot)•First off, the vehicle controls are really broken and wonky. Fortunately, you only use a vehicle twice in the game, and it's optional one of those times.•As I mentioned earlier, the character customization felt a little restricted. For some odd reason, the genders are tied onto the species, which means you can't have a male Zabrak(Darth Maul's species) or a female Keldor(Plo Koon's species).•The lip-sync is pretty bad, and so is Luke's voice actor, but these were only minor annoyances.I highly recommend this game, and I guarantee you'll love it. That is unless you hate Star Wars...

												This was one of my favorite games growing up as a child. I have owned a disk copy of the game since I was 9 years old and have logged several hundred hours in both campaign and multiplayer. The game has a nice story, playing as an unknown jedi wannabe with a lightsaber as you train to become a jedi master one day. The online gameplay is great, with the game usually having a great fanbase who after 12 years are still playing this game religiously. For those who don't want to fight with only lightsabers, there is a nice selection of other weapons as well (I reccomend the disruper rifle. That's my personal favorite). Because this game is 12 years old, it can run well on almost any computer you install it on, but the graphics are still really good for how old it is. The lightsabers are beautiful with nice lighting, sound, and motion. Overall, I give this game an 11/10.

content:
6, 2016
												Mit "Jedi Academy" fand die altehrwürdige Jedi-Knight Reihe (leider) einen - hoffentlich nur vorläufigen - Abschluss. Dabei ist das Spiel kein offizieller dritter Teil sondern nur ein Ableger der Reihe. Was mit Dark Forces als eine Art "Star Wars Doom" begann, ging mit "Jedi Knight" und der Erweiterung "Mysteries of the Sith" weiter bis hin zu dem ebenfalls grandiosen "jedi Knight II - Jedi Outcast", welches 2002 zum Kinostart von Episode 2 erschien. Letzteres wurde von der Kritik hochgelobt, neben der tollen Grafik und Action war das Spiel auch atmosphärisch ausgezeichnet gelungen. Auch die original Synchronstimmen von Luke Skywalker und Lando Calrissian trugen das Ihre dazu bei. Ein Jahr später legten die Raven Studios dann mit Jedi Academy nach. Storytechnisch und grafisch macht das Spiel im Vergleich zum Vorgänger leider keine großen Fortschritte. Allerdings muss man bedenken, dass es nach wie vor auf der Quake III-Arena Engine von 1999 basiert. Die war eben auch 2002 schon veraltet, leiste abseits der etwas altbackenen Optik aber nach wie vor ausgezeichnete Arbeit. Die Schusswechsel und hohen Jedi-Sprünge gehen absolut intuitiv von der Hand. Da fühlt man sich tatsächlich etwas an Quake III erinnert. Was das Spiel aber von seinem großen Uhrahn abhebt, und gerade auch als Star Wars Spiel einzigartig macht, sind die grandiosen Lichschwertkämpfe. Diese laufen im Gegensatz zu den Schusswechseln standartmäßig in der Third-Person Ansicht ab und wirken - obwohl Teil des aktiven Gameplays - absolut perfekt szeneastisch Inszeniert. In modernen Actionspielen wäre das, was man hier "live" zu sehen bekommt, allenfalls als stupide Quick-Time-Events ins Spiel eingebunden - siehe The Force Unleashed. Lediglich in Spielen von Platinum Games wie Bayonetta oder Vanquish und mit Abstrichen vielleicht in DMC kann man heute noch derart intensive Nahkampf-Aktion aktiv erleben. Und die Lichtschwert Duelle sowie die Machtkräfte sind es, die sich im Vergleich zu "Jedi Outcast" wirklich verbessert haben. So wirkt der Machtblitz jetzt irgendwie wuchtiger, und ist auch grafisch weit schöner anzuschauen. Auch sind neue Kräfte hinzugekommen, wie der Machtentzug und die Rage. Mir scheinen irgendwie auch die Lichtschwertkämpfe noch intuitiver und flüssiger zu laufen - obwohl die in "Jedi Outcast" auch schon die absoluten Höhepunkte bildeten. Die Kämpfe enden in äußerst sehenswerten Finishing Moves, bei denen die Sith auch schon mal das ein oder andere Körperteil verlieren. Seine USK 16-Werung hat das Spiel somit verdient. Außerdem ist es jetzt möglich, sich im Laufe des Spiels ein Doppelschwert anzufertigen oder zwei Lichtschwerter auf einmal zu führen. Dies verändert die Lichtschwertkämpfe spürbar, und erhöht zusammen mit den verscheidenen Spezies, die als Hauptcharaktere zur Wahl stehen, den Wiederspielwert enorm. Außerdem kann man sich im Laufe des Spiels entscheiden, zur dunklen Seite zu wechseln, was aber nur die Story etwas abändert und wenig Auswirkungen auf das Gameplay hat. Die Story sehe ich tatsächlich als den größten Schwachpunkt des Spiels. Sie ist irgendwie sehr Standartmäßig gestrickt: Neuer Sithkult bedroht die neue Republik, neuer Jedi muss sich dem in den Weg stellen. Auch deshalb, weil die Missionen in verschiedenen Reihenfolgen gespielt werden können - was eigentlich eine super Idee ist - kommt kein richtiger Erzählfluss auf. Diese Mängel werden für mich aber durch das absolut geniale Gameplay, tolle Star-Wars Atmosphäre und das tolle Leveldesign mehr als Wettgemacht. Storymäßig macht es natürlich Sinn, mit Dark Forces anzufangen. Leider ist dies im deutschen Steam Store nicht mehr erhältlich, weil es in Deutschland lächerlicherweise auf dem Index ist, und sich keiner die Mühe macht, es von dort zu entfernen. Ein Schicksal, welches sein älterer Bruder Doom lange mit ihm teilte. Daher empfehle ich, mit dem ersten Jedi Knight einzusteigen.

content:
y 9, 2016
												This is the best Star Wars game I've played, other than KOTOR. (Although honestly I haven't played KOTOR II or any of the other Jedi Knight games.) •The combat system is the best I've seen in a Star Wars game. •The missions are fun and challenging, even on the regular difficulty. •The main game is long enough without being too long(unless you're as bad as I am). •There is a nice amount of character customization, but the species choices are a bit lacking. •The graphics still hold up well for a game that was made over a decade ago. •And there is still online multiplayer that is pretty fun.Now, for the bad stuff (which isn't a lot)•First off, the vehicle controls are really broken and wonky. Fortunately, you only use a vehicle twice in the game, and it's optional one of those times.•As I mentioned earlier, the character customization felt a little restricted. For some odd reason, the genders are tied onto the species, which means you can't have a male Zabrak(Darth Maul's species) or a female Keldor(Plo Koon's species).•The lip-sync is pretty bad, and so is Luke's voice actor, but these were only minor annoyances.I highly recommend this game, and I guarantee you'll love it. That is unless you hate Star Wars...

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
er 27, 2014
												What a great Star Wars adventure! I originally got this game way back in 2011 but never bothered to finish it due to some silly mission I was stuck in - I'm glad that Steam saved my game files so I could finally get back around to it. And oh man, what have I been missing - this game is just amazingly fun.On your travels as jedi academy student Jaden Korr you'll be under the tutelage of Kyle Katarn (the protagonist of the Jedi Knight series) and Luke Skywalker himself facing enemies such as the Imperial Remnants and the Disciples of Ragnos (evil Jedi with force powers). The storyline is pretty simplistic, but it has its moments including fighting a top a moving tram and escaping from a mutated Rancor while it breaks the entire level apart.  The game has a system where you can play the levels in any order which really helps with the pacing - apart from the few ridiculous "the ground is lava" and "defuse all the bombs hidden in the level" missions, they're all very enjoyable and have great level design. The villain is pretty generic and dull, but since the nature of the game is varied missions directed from the Jedi Academy it doesn't really need a strong plotline with interesting characters. Only little complaint was that the later levels have a lot of annoying Force Jump puzzles (even a conveyor platforming puzzle level, come on now). The lightsaber combat makes the game - the actual first person shooter mechanics are okay at best, but the sheer fun factor of the game comes from slicing and dicing your enemies with your lightsaber, flipping around the map with awesome Force powers. You can force choke, shoot lightning out of your hands and flip across walls. You can customize your character and even change the color of your lightsabers. Around the halfway point of the game (as you ascend to the position of a Jedi Knight) you can choose a single lightsaber, dual lightsabers or a double lightsaber. I played through the game with dual lightsabers and it was really fantastic how each of the lightsaber styles have their own movesets and mechanics to use.The multiplayer of the original is long dead but the modding community still has a few servers up - I recommend the "Movie Battles 2" mod for a great Star Wars experience that showcases the battles of the universe, and for people that like the original trilogy, you can duel Luke Skywalker vs Darth Vader in the "Movie Duels 2" mod.The game hasn't aged as much as I thought it had. There's a little labyrinthe level design in the missions, but otherwise it's a quality Star Wars adventure that won't leave you cold - interesting combat, timeless setting and just plain fun gameplay. Go get it!

												First off I bought Jedi Knight Jedi Academy at wal mart a looong time ago and put hours and hours into this Awesome title so dont let the steam hours fool you..Out of all the Star Wars games that had Lightsaber fighting Jedi Knight Jedi Academy Is hands down the best. er 27, 2011
												Despite being relatively old, it's still my favourite Star Wars game. I've played many Star Wars games and none of them felt quite as right as this one. SW KOTOR was too RPG, SW TOR is too expensive, and the rest of the SW games feel either too arcade or standart FPS, but this one is the perfect fast-paced action adventure style SW. Lightsaber duels, character/force/lightsaber customisation, tons of mods and skins, classic MP modes {yes, people still play it}, rich campaign and more. The game features both FPS and TPS perspectives, you can adapt the game to your own play style, can use several lightsabers or weapons or both if you must, and every lightsaber technique has unique moves and combos. If you're looking for some fun enjoyable action game, go for the SW Jedi Academy.

content:
er 19, 2010
												There was a time when Star Wars games were not actually terrible. The Jedi Knight series has always been great, pushing the boundaries of large maps and open world design. This is the final entry and more or less a standalone expansion to Jedi Outcast. It is the least revolutionary of the series but easiest for beginners and also has the full set of features and an awesome community full of mods and maps to choose from. As for gameplay it has the most complete lightsaber battle experience out there and a feature packed multiplayer. Not just a good Star Wars game, but a great game in general. Looks a little dated on quake3 engine but you'll forgive it based on fun factor.

content:
8, 2015
8/10Recommended PurchaseIf you enjoyed this review,consider giving it a thumbs up!ProsCombatThe combat in this game is very unique. You can either use one of your different blaster weapons which are terrible against dark jedi but can seriously damage other units like stormtroopers from range. You also can use your lightsaber to cut through dark jedi and just about everything else with ease.This game really shines in the saber vs. saber combat as you can have these epic battles with the dark jedi. You actually have many different moves like backwards flips and slashes and you have to use all of these to take on the strongest of Dark Jedi.LevelsThere are quite a few little fun puzzles in this game and plently of epic landscapes to match ranging from the tombs of Korriban all the way to crime syndicates of Coruscant.There are also quite alot of secret areas where you can pick up multiple extra medpacks,blaster ammunition,or shields. Most aren't very well hidden and usually just require looking in a different direction but still its a nice little bit of help.Force PowersThere are a multitude of powers you can use to demolish your enemies and heal yourself. Powers ranging from Force heal all the way to lightning and saber throw provide quite a lot of variety to your combat experience.Whether or not you take a bunch of dark powers of more light-sided powers the game reacts to that. So if you begin to sway more towards the dark side,when you return from a mission Luke may tell you that you are drifting towards the dark and that you must resist its influence.ConsPlotTo be honest the plot in this game is pretty okay but not much more. Nothing too interesting but at least its not abysmal. None of the characters are too interesting but there aren't a whole lot of characters I would say I hated either. The main problem with the plot is that its not enough.You do 3 non-story missions and then you get some story but its just too split apart and fractured.Facial AnimationsThe facial animations really bug me. They dont even look remotely like what the character is trying to say half the time and the other half its still rather poor. I get its an older game but still this is pretty bad even still.If you found this review helpful or entertaining then feel free to join my Steam Curator Group at  Mudkips Gaming

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
y 19, 2016
												Rating: 9/10Budget: Worth itLenght: It takes a skilled player at least two days to beat the single player campaign. It features a great multiplayer mode, and even still (2016) has an online multiplayer community, but good luck beating the average Wizard who still plays this! Replayability: I tend to replay it once every two-three years, but it has good replayability mainly because the game features and advancement system, a some incredibly memorable and fun missions and two endings. Imagine if Jedi Outcast didn't have a 100% linear story, came with character creation and even the option to pick what fighting style you wanted to use, choose your lightsaber color and hilt and had a non-linear character advancement system. In Academy, you advance your character by getting 1 new force power per level you beat. There are 5 levels per segment of the game - Each segment is separated by a number of story missions that you have to beat. You can actually beat only 4 missions per segment if you want, and advance without beating the final mission - This is a good way to avoid that one mission you hate, but unfortunately, the game doesn't let you know how this actually works! My friend did this, thinking he could just do the mission he skipped later, but that wasn't the case - and he missed out on a fun mission and a force power. Unlike in Jedi Outcast, in this game you start as a Jedi with a lightsaber. In the very first mission, your only force power is lightsaber throw Rank 1 (not sure why they even gave you this one!), but you do start with a lightsaber, but from mission two and onwards, you have access to force powers at level 1, and after the second game segment you get to pick if you wanna upgrade to dual lightsaber, a saber staff or master the one saber. After the first segment, you get to pick if you want the strong style or the fast style. You can advance your powers in the game how ever you want, but it's recommended to take the first rank of healing. I actually personally recommend not taking further ranks, because I feel it makes the game too easy. Enemies do not use healing, except through force drain (taking YOUR health), a very ineffective method of healing to be frank, so I feel it makes the game too easy to have the ability to heal while fighting also. Without healing though, the game is next to impossible to beat, because unlike in Outcast, you can't pick up bacta tanks and use them when you're hurt, and there are fewer medkits around. The game has a bit of a learning curve, and is outdated in the graphics department, but there are mods that help with that. Over all, a great game.

content:
1, 2016
												Okay - so I have had the game for two days and have put 9 hours into it, so it's not like I have the amount of experience with the game that other reviewers do. With that being said, I have a pretty firm opinion of the game: it is amazing! Not often do I think to myself "wow, this game is great!" and have difficulty putting it down and doing something else. This game made my think just that, and I have barely been able to pry myself from the computer the last two days. So, long story short, I love this game. It's lightsaber combat is wonderful, containing flurishes, kicks, and other super cool moves. I really enjoy the story as well. Not to mention that the game still has a very active online multiplayer. I would give this a solid 9.5/10 (and the reason that it gets a .5 deduction from a perfect score is one annoying mission that I could not get past, ergh!).As a kid I played Jedi Knight II: Jedi Outcast on my gamecube and it was one of my favorite games. Jedi Academy is a wonderful game that brought me back to when I was 6 years old, having to ask my step-dad to help me beat Jedi Outcast. And for only $10, this game is most certianly worth the buy.

content:
y 14, 2015
												     This game is the best RPG in the future EU of Star Wars. The Characters, Character Customization, and Story are bad. The Gameplay and Power Customization are good. The Character Customization is very small, and there is "five" combat styles and four powers for each side (dark and light), plus neutral powers. The gameplay is solid, and there is enough customization for each side, but the story is mediocre, and it somehow has more customization in multiplayer (which is very fun) and there is no replay value. The levels are very linear, except for keyhunts, and the enemies are squishy and easy to blow, except for force and lightsaber users.     You can get more styles, like medium, fast and strong. Later you ***** your **** with ***** and then your ***** becomes evil, you can get two lightsaber and or a double sided one, Darth Maul Style, and colors, except red. In multiplayer you can choose red lightsaber and changing characters (or use standart models) and you can choose you force powers in a way superior than the campaign. You start with a finite points, and used them in different powers.     The campaign has five side missions, you do at least four and you unlock the main mission. Each mission allows you to choose one point to the your increasily force arsenal, and choose weapons to use. The story is bland, but the gameplay is very fun, and powering up  your arsenal is fun. There is one mission that your fellow classmates attack with you, and I hoped that there were more missions like that.     I didn't play any other dark forces games, but I wished there were more downloadable missions, multiplayer maps, and customization. I liked it and recomend it and I played the campaign in 20 hours, and playing six on multiplayer. I thought it could be remade with modern technology, and more features, and maybe co-op.     Summary: Good Gameplay, Bad Story. Good Game, needs more Content, 20~hours and I like it, so you should too.

content:
er 3, 2013
												OVERVIEW: 8/10 I will warn you, this is a fairly long review :)I originally owned this game on the first Xbox, where it was one of my most played games. While being backwards compatible with the Xbox 360 the game does not natively support a 360 controller, however, third party software such as Xpadder may be used to get around this, although there seems to be an issue with the game's use of the x-axis.The story itself takes place after the Jedi Outcast games (which unfortunately I never played) with the player taking the role of an upcoming student under the tutilage of Kyle Katarn (protagonist of previous Jedi Knight games) at Luke Skywalker's academy on Yavin 4. While the voice acting is sub-par, the game quickly gives you the ability to complete missions in the order of your chosing as well as allowing you to utilise different means to dispatch enemies. This means that despite being a Jedi padawan, the game still gives you the option of engaging with your enemies using weapons such as a blaster pistol or a bowcaster, as well as thermal detonators and trip mines. Combining these tools with force powers such as Grip, Pull and Push allow you to be 'creative' in your manner of killing.All of this 'freedom' however is within a linear sandbox. The missions themselves dont all feel sequential and thus disconnected from the others, almost as if they are merely fillers between the main story missions. You could alternatively state that this is done in order to create an 'authentic' experience; under the guise of allowing you to choose the order of the missions given to you, the missions act as a means of learning how to effectively utilise the skills you have in order to be successful in the main missions which drive forward the narrative. As the story does progress, players have to option to level up force powers from both the Light and Dark sides respectively, which depending on which abilities you mostly use in a mission, earns a comment from either Luke or Kyle about how your objective was met. What I percieved to be the pinnacle of the game was when you accquired max level in all of your neutral force powers; at this time you were given the option to use a single, dual or a double bladed lightsaber - giving you access to amazingly stylised combinations of attack.Multiplayer on this game is a confusing one for me. While it does support local bot play, there are some issues with connecting to servers. These range from not actually being able to find any, to the game freezing while you try to connect to one. Some of these issues may be due to either the server or the client your using having mods which conflict installed - this brings me to another point; mod support.An outdated game such as this may turn people off solely due to the graphics. Well, for those that find this an issue, there are retexture packs out there for you to use install which do boost up the games appearance. There are also numerous mods for the game aswell; Movie Battles II and Knights of the Force are two I highly recommend you check out, as these increase the customisation of the lightsabers as well as giving you access to both locations and characters from the films.Overall, I give this game an 8 out of 10. It's not the best Star Wars game I've played (that title belongs to KotOR) but it was the first Star Wars game I played which felt like I had a variety of ways to complete my objectives. For its time the combat was brilliant and provides an authentic Jedi experience.WARNING: Towards the later stages of the game, players are faced with a choice (don't worry I wont spoil what it is). This choice however, appeared on screen in small text and for a short period of time. This may not be the case for the PC port, but I'd thought I'd give you a heads up in advance.

content:
2016
												Jedi Academy is, simply put, one of the best Star Wars games I've ever played. The story is ... okay, I guess? It's not bad but it's no BioWare KOTOR epic story. Whatever. It's got some interesting (no longer canon, thanks Disney) stuff about ancient Sith Lords that's cool if you're into (no-longer-canon) lore. The graphics are pretty good, especially for a 2003 game they've held up pretty well. But the game is really significant for one very important reason. No Star Wars game before or since has ever captured the feeling of wielding a lightsaber as well as this one. You know, that thing all of us who have ever seen a Star Wars movie have always dreamed of? This is the game that does it best. Other Star Wars games at best make you feel like you're wielding a regular sword that's been given a Star Wars mod. In Jedi Academy, I felt like I was truly wielding a deadly beam of light. I'm a traditional one-saber kind of gal myself, but I also love how the game put real thought into developing fighting styles for wielding 2 lightsabers or a double-bladed Darth Maul style saber as well. I also really like the ability to choose between a variety of missions instead of being forced along a totally strict linear path. It's not anywhere near total sandbox freedom, but being able to quit out of a frustrating mission and try a different one instead is nice.tl;dr: THE BEST LIGHTSABER COMBAT IN ANY STAR WARS GAME EVER
