content:
y 22, 2014
												Star Wars Jedi Knight Jedi Academy is a great game. Star Wars is great on its own. But I'm here today to talk about the final game in the Jedi Knight Saga. Jedi Academy. Jedi Academy starts off with you creating your character. There are a few lightsaber colours and hilts to choose from, but nothing much. You can customise your character and change them to one of six races, three being Male and three being Female. After you have created your character, lightsaber and everything, you find yourself on a shuttle. That shuttle gets shot down and you crash. And guess what - the person you just met came out with you. Makes sense, doesn't it?So, you make your way to the Jedi Temple, and here is where the game really begins. After a training session with Kyle Katarn, your Jedi instructor and protagonist of the prequel, you are given a set of six missions. There are three sets of these missions throughout the game. The first ones are easy, the second ones are harder, and the last one is just too hard. But I don't mind, seeing as I have finished the game 11 or 12 times. ;DThe final level *SPOILER* is you venturing through the catacombs trying to find Tavion (main villain of the game). In the previous level, you can choose whether to go with the Dark Side or stay on the Good Side. If you choose Dark Side, it durastically increases the difficulty of the level. EVERYONE is against you. Not one life form on that level is with you. And then in the boss fight, you fight Tavion and kill her, and then Katarn. (Tavion is trying to revive Ractos (I think it's Ractos)) If you choose the Good Side, then the Jedi are on your side and help you fight the Sith. The final boss is Tavion then Ractos's spirit going inside her...O_O And then you defeat her(him...hehehe) and then blah blah blah you win the game thanks for playing credits. *SUMMARY*Jedi Academy in my opinion is the greatest Star Wars game. EVER. I give it a 10/10. It's a game from my childhood, what can I say? So learn the force, craft a saber, go out there and stop Tavion!

content:
er 15, 2015
												Star Wars Jedi Knight Academy: Tactical Saber Action+ Extremely fun but sometimes clunky gameplay.+ Simple and linear level design, with a few levels falling short.+ Engaging and simple story.+ Good voice acting for the time.+ Good framerate, works on modern systems, seldom crashes.+ A very comfy game+ Fun multiplayer- Extremely dated cutscenes and animations, even for a 2004 game.- Some levels in particular can be a dread to play, the level design can be pretty awkward.- Stupidly sparse checkpoints, you'll want to quicksave a LOT to avoid redoing everything.- Gameplay can be so weird and clunky, the slices can be too hard to control.- No 1920x1080 support, you have to change the game's files in order to get it.- The game can feel like a pretty low budget early 2000s PC game at times.7/10. It's still a fun game, just extremely flawed. I'd recommend it just for the multiplayer alone, especially for Star Wars fans.

content:
y 9, 2014
												Even better than its predecessor (Jedi Outcast) and a little less challenging. But more customiazble, you start off by choosing what species you character can be, and your single lightsaber, (Blade colour and hilt) and start off.Enter Yavin 4 and the Jedi Academy, progressing through your first force trials and chatting to good ol' Luke Skywalker. You then get sent off to your frist set of 5 mission, (only 4 needed to be completed to pass through to the 1st story level but you can complete all 5) At the beginning of each mission, you can choose to level up a force power, both light and dark. It will be upgraded by 1 point, with a max of 3 points all over to get the ability to its full potential. Your character then gets more focused on the storyline, with a 'story mission' where you will go to a strong point of the Disciples of Ragnos. This happens all the way through the game. This game has some epic lightsaber battles later in the game, and also has a wide variety of weapons and force powers. This game and Jedi Outcast both have multiplayer with some great maps and games, such as capture the flag and free for all. Recommended to anybody looking for a cool adventure, and fans of star wars.Worth its price.

content:
ry 8, 2015
												This game was created to demonstrate how mentally challenged siths are.There are several ways to deal with siths, the least efficient being actually fighting them in a lightsaber duel:-Stand on a platform in lava and watch as they try to walk through lava to get to you-Fire grenades at them and watch as they jump into an abyss to avoid said grenade-Convert a stormtrooper with your wololo mind tricks and watch as they completely ignore you cutting up their back as they fight said stormtrooper-Jump on a tall object, wait until they follow, then jump off and watch as they fall to their death jumping after you-Have them get stuck in some corner (which happens all the time)-Blowing them up with a rocket launcher-Luring them on top of an electric conduit-Running past them and completely ignore them-Lure them under an elevator and watch as they get squished-Lure them on a conveyor belt and watch as they get squished or killed by hot steam-Lure them to poison godzilla and watch as poison godzilla grabs them through a wallYou have plenty of opportunities to try all of these as the developers think game difficulty can be measured in siths per minute (SPM), expect SPM to increase the further you progress in the game.Oh and you can draw lines on walls using your lightsaber which is fun.Also tasteless Boba Fett retcon.

content:
ry 5, 2015
												In my opinion this is the greatest gem among the Star Wars Jedi first person games (Dark Forces, Jedi Outcast, etc.).I just discovered it in a bundle, but it is well worth the normal full price anytime. You will definitely get an awesome experience for your money.The only negative point (if any), is that widescreen resolutions aren't supported so you will either get ugly black bars or distorted images. It's not too bad on my Full HD screen though and the max resolution itself can go even higher than that.EDIT: Because it was so very helpful, I decided to paste the comment I received to this review:Marto 12 Feb @ 6:32pmYou can have widescreen if you edit jaconfig.cfg file, located usually in ...\Steam\steamapps\common\Jedi Academy\GameData\base folderadd following:seta r_customheight "1200"seta r_customwidth "1920"seta r_mode "-1"or whatever resolution you want and you wil have widescreen perspective.

content:
4, 2015
												This game takes up all of my free time.Every single minute of fee time i have and obtain goes towards this game, and this is by far my most played game, so I am a tristed reviewer.This game is thoroughly enjoyable, I loved the space farming mechanics, and I own 5 space cows named Bessie, Jessie, Messie, Lessie, and Hank.  The name of this game is a little discerning however, as even after putting all the time I have into this game, I'm still not sure what a Jedi Knight is.  Also, I STILL dont know what a Star Wars is, or why it is in all capitals, but I enjoyed the game none the less.Another part of the game that is very enjoyable is the combat system, using farts as a propellant/transport for your character is very innovative and I have taken to even using this method in real life.  This game has overall changed my life, I just cant get enough of it and this game will probably continue to be my most played game untill I die.I 100% recomend SPACE BATTLEZ Star Knight - Astronaut Academy for fans of games like Hatoful Boyfriend, Castle Crashers, and Sexfriend Ultimate 2012.

content:
ber 3, 2014
												If you like men dancing around in tights waving flashlights, this the best starwars title out there. STormtroopers ftw!The pros:The combat is just awesome and visually fun to watch even for these days. The story is tolerably enticing. You're able to use a wide selection of iconic starwars weapons like blaster rifles and thermal detonaters. You are also able to use a single saber, dual sabers, and a saber staff (double bladed hilt) and each has pros and cons, making you able to be just as effective with each. You are also able to customize your force powers  giving it slight RPG feel, and you can have access potentially to all the good stuff. Lighting and force grip and force push OH MY!The cons: When fighting multiple sith, you're liable to get stabbed in the back when you're in a saber lock with the other.Mass genocide of storm troopers. Truly sad to watch.9/10 Would force choke a trandoshian again.

content:
er 23, 2013
												You think of a lot of Star Wars games and you're probably thinking of Republic Commando, Battlefront, Knights of The Old Republic and so on. This is the game that I think everyone, even if you're not a fan of Star Wars, should play it. As mentioned in PCGamer, it makes the lightsabers feel like sabers rather than a neon stick with high damage. These lightsabers are rods of superheated plasma, and my god does it let you know that. Stand close enough to a wall, and where your saber would clip through the wall, it cuts it, leaving a burning trail through the wall. If it rains, the water hisses and makes steam. These babies are also one or two hit kills too - you can chop off your enemies limbs with finesse if you're fast enough. There is absolutely nothing stopping you from never using a gun (apart from one mission where you are captured), and the sabers themselves also have a vareity of unique moves depending on which saber you can choose. Yes, you can customise your saber. Colour, hilt and type. Want Darth Maul's red saber staff? You can choose red as your colour in MP (or if you want, pick an aggressive shade of orange. The purple is also known for striking fear into the hearts of your enemies). You can also customise your character. In fact, the only solid thing is your name, the helpfully ambigous Jaden Korr. Your race, gender and clothing is up to you. Also the female player is voiced buy Jennifer Hale, otherwise known as female Shepard.The multiplayer community is also somewhat active, but remember, if you're a beginner to the saber (even if you've finished the game) there is always that one guy who is just better than you. It can be aggravating, but get some friends, and it's amazing.

content:
y 28, 2014
												I say this game is reccomened but only to a true Star Wars fan. For the most part the game is fun but there are moments where I wanted to rage quit.Firstly, the enemies. Basic gun enemies (strom troopers etc.) quickly become easy to kill and pose no challenge after a few missions. Enemies with lightsabres are another story, they can use every power you can making them pretty much your equal, what isn't equal is when you have to fight multiple at once. At several points in the game, the game expected me to take on 5 enemy jedi at once (so I ran past them), but the most frustrating thing is when you kill them. Every time you kill an enemy jedi with your lightsabre, the game decides to do a full 360 spin of your player. It looks cool at first but it wears off quickly and if you kill one enemy jedi when another one is about to attack you, you have to dodge by mmoving, but since the camera is doing a 360 spin, moving in the right direction is hard to do.Secondly, the force powers. You get given powers like force push, pull, jump etc. given to you at the start of the game and they level up those skills as you progress through the story. Then there are other force powers that you can choose to level up before each misson (cure, lightning, shield etc.). Each force power has 3 levels, some powers are very overpowered and others are totally useless (just be sure to experiment with every force power). The other problem is that your force is limited by a constantly recharging metre. But this metre charges very slowly and when using some powers, it doesn't charge at all, a lot of my time in the game was hitting an enemy with force lightning, running round until my metre recharged and repeating, I would have prefered the metre recharge quicker to make combat flow better.There's also a lot of little things like enemies insulting you because you ran away to recharge your force or to avoid combat (and it's made even worse since the enemies can shout at you from a really far distance)That said, there are still some fun and fair challenges during the middle part of the game and there are cool tricks you can do    like throwing your lightsabre and juming up walls (a lot of these special abilities take a while to master).People who love Star Wars will like this game more than other people, just be ready for rage (and don't be ashamed to use a walkthrough)Overall an good game 6.5/10

content:
r 5, 2016
												Following on from Jedi Knights Outcast, comes a game I enjoyed a little more.  I played this game a long time ago, so knew what to expect, but after recently playing Outcast, I prefer this game a little more.The story follows on the story in Outcast, where someone you've fought was left alive, and now she's back.  This time however, you play as a young Jedi in training, working along side, Kyle Katarn.You can choose your species and gender before starting, and as the game progresses, can choose your lightsaber, fighting style and force powers, whereas in Outcast, you were on a set path.  The game also has light and dark endings, which gives it a little more replay value.  The missions are not linear in a sence of following a strict timeline, so you can even mix it up that way.Combat wise, its basically the same as Outcast.  Gun play is fine, although you learn why everyone is such a terrible shot.  Not as many Stormtroopers as Outcast, so see a variety of different species, which makes things different.Lightsaber duels are a little better I found than Outcast.  But that's maybe just down to a different move set you can have over the standard Katarn one; I'm not sure.  Like Outcast, and because I'm terrible, playing on Easy Mode was a mix bag for me.  100 health, and can fight for ages and never deal damage, then die with one swing from the AI.  Othertimes, one swing and a jump from me and they go down.  Not much feedback on dealing damage I found.Levels are SO much simpler to work out than Outcast.  I had a terrible time figuring out where to go, and what to do, with some backtracking required.  Academy though is a lot more condensed, and a lot more linear, which for this type of single player story, is a lot easier to work with.Overall, a good enough game.  Recommend it, and I'm sure you can pick it up with Outcast in a Star Wars bundle.

												Better than one would have thought.I found this on the Star Wars Humble Bundle and bought and downloaded it, as I did the rest, and as it turns out, it was VERY good!The gameplay is great,the campaign is fairly short, the controls are fine but can be a bit annoying,the graphics are acceptable for it's time.The duels with the sith are, believe it or not, very unique. The AI for most of the enemies wasn't that great, but the sith seemed to be increasingly difficult as the game went on. The duels felt like they should and have truly captured the essence of lightsaber battles. The development of the force powers as the game goes on makes these duels incredibly breathtaking and very, very enjoyable.Overall, I would say this game is one of those hidden treasures that you can find and, while you may not have heard of it, absolutely blow you away. I'd not heard of this game before until I bought the Star Wars Humble Bundle and am really wishing I'd known of it sooner and have recently bought the sequel which seems to be much more difficult but not as good as this one.

11, 2015
												Finding a Star Wars video game that actually isnt complete dogsh*te is a big ask, luckily Jedi Academy is a blast. It isn't particularly sophisticated. You can swing a lightsaber around and use a collection of force powers, that's pretty much it, There is a good sense of progression as you go along unlocking more powers and lightsabers without ever become OP plus dueling other jedi's/dark jedi's/sith etc is surprisingly fun seeing how simple the combat is. You also get to ride a tauntaun at one point, if that won't sell it for you then I don't know what will.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
8, 2015
												Ever wanted to summon a hundred sith and 20 Luke Skywalkers to see how they fare against each other? You can do it in this game! (with cheats though). Also, this game has a rather interesting single player story mode I played through multiple times and sank approximately 40 hours into. Click here for an Under 5 Min Review of this game!Pros:1. You can be a Jedi! Also, it has Kyle Katarn and Luke Skywalker in it!2. A plethora of mods!3. Although the story is linear, the levels offer a variety of experiences (crashlanding on a planet and repairing your ship, while trying to escape a sand worm; fighting Boba Fett; disarming a bomb-rigged train; speeder chase, and many other routine adventures a Jedi Padawan/Knight goes through)4. Awesome acrobatics, swordsplay and Force powers, which feel way more fluid and natural to the game than the guns.5. Great sandboxing potential of both SP and MP. You think this plain on Tatooine would make a great battlefield? Spawn in Boba Fett and 3 Kyle Katarns and see who wins, then spawn in 20 Boba Fetts and 60 Kyles. (spoiler: Boba Fett wins every time, since he's immortal). Would you make this roof to roof jump on the moving train if you had a speeder with you? Spawn in a speeder and try it out!6. There is an active multiplayer community and the sandbox is real on the servers (there are banks, quests and other different RPG-ish kinds of stuff). There are some classic FFA, TDM or CTF servers too. While the sandbox is something very interesting and unique to this game, I can't really say it was that big of a deal for me.Cons:1. Dated graphics and cinematics.2. Very predictable and linear story.3. Gunplay is pretty subpar, compared to lightsaber combat and Force powers.4. Possible compatibility problems with Windows 7/8. Also, some tinkering is required before you can set it to 16:9.This is one of the games, that aged really well, considering it's over 10 years old. If older graphics are a problem for you, there are mods partially fixing them, as well as adding a bunch of new things to the game. The most fun I've had with this game was either by spawning in enemies and allies and organising battles royale, or trying to get speeder jumps in original places (for example a roof to roof jump on the moving train level). I return to this game every now and then for the great lightsaberplay and to have some fun cheating in enemies and vehicles.You might encounter compatibility problems, so purchase at your own risk!Verdict: 9/10 - Would get choked by Kyle Katarn again (no homo).

content:
y 28
												This game is a technical mess, a narrative disaster, that also still manages to be kinda fun. Weird, right?The game barely works. It's as if every mechanic in the game was loosely coded and then given 0 polish. You character moves with little precision, and the lightsaber is almost complete blind hack n' slash. The gunplay is... ok I guess. The blasters all feel like blasters and have neat dual firing modes. The enemies are consistently inconsistent, often times being completely ineffective, glitchy, and then switching on the fly to Dead-eye ♥♥♥♥♥ and killing you very quickly. I was fortunate to not have any hardware issues, and had a good FPS.The story is pretty terrible. What's there is mostly just mountains of OT references, and what isn't is usually painfully awkward dialogue, or just dumb writing. Is this what people think Star Wars is?That said, it's hard to find another game that lets you bounce around, zippin' and slashin' like a Jedi and sh*t. If that's all you wanted, I recommend this game. If you were looking for some depth or something.... more? Then I do no recommend this game. I'm still gonna play it once and a while whenever the ol' internet's down... so there's that I guess.

content:
4, 2014
												This is simply one of those classic Star Wars games that defines a generation... I can personally say that this game features one of the most diverse and enjoyable leveling experience that I have ever had the privilege to enjoy. Not only does it feature complex puzzle and mechanics, but it has incredible combat as it is powered by the Quake 3 engine. Not only does this make for a boredom-free leveling experience, but it is also allows for some of the most challenging and entertaining PvP. While the combat is superior to it's predecessor due to brand new combos, force abilities, and the addition of Jar'Kai duel wielding and double-bladed saber staffs, the story is very much lacking as it is cluttered with plot holes and meaningless absurd plot devices. Fortunately, the positives of this game easily out-weigh the awful story. As a whole this game is an incredible feat, let alone for something made over a decade ago and is certainly worth the minimal fee of $10. In addition to this game I'd like to recommend a few other classic Star Wars titles including: Knights of the Old Republic, KotOR: the Sith Lords, Battlefront 2, and the rest of the Dark Forces series if you are into older games. I also recommend a mod called "Jedi Outcast - Academy mod" Which can be found on moddb.com and allows you to play the full Jedi Outcast campaign on the updated Jedi Academy engine. With that I leave you, and remember the Dark Side has cookies and force lightning is over-powered. >:D

content:
, 2016
												I do not regret playing this game, I simply believe there are other games that may be more worthy of paying 10+ hours of your life to experience.Depth: 5/10Story: 7/10Replayability: 6/10Controls: 4/10Value: 9/10 (Paid $2.50 for it, got over 10 hours out of it)Momentum: 5/10Memorability: 3/10 Time Debt: 3.5/10Overall: 5/10*By "Momentum" I mean, the extent to which I wanted to keep playing the game at any instance during gameplay. For example: "Quake" for the xbox 360 was one of the most painful games I've ever played, and I only continued the game because I was an achievement ♥♥♥♥♥.  It would get a 1/10.*By "Memorability" I mean the extent to which my life was made richer by experiencing this game, i.e., was this a game that I'll be thinking about and talking about with friends years down the road?*By "Time Debt" I mean the extent to which I believe this game was worth the time it took to beat the game, i.e., in hindsight would I agree that there were no other things I would've rather spent my 10+ hours on? Notable Mentions:-Occasionally there are areas/levels which have repetative audio segments, which can get really annoying. (Looking at you Blenjeel merchant rescue!!!)-There seems to be an instant jump in difficulty midway through the game.  Not necessarily a bad thing, just different from the usual.-Force Lightning.  Always a good decision, regardless of star wars game. Hah-I went through the game using mostly a lightsaber.  On normal difficulty, lightsaber combat was really just kind of hack & slash with little thought needed.  On normal, it's very much so a scratch-ur-balls-while-playing kind of game.All these ratings are based on 2016 expectations.  For its time I believe this game could've easily been an 8/10 or higher.

content:
28
												I feel conflicted about this game.Pros--Character custamization. (Oh, its really cool, from your face to your clothes to your lightsaber! Might not be as indepth as our modern standerd but still cool.)-First person shooter and Hack'n'slash. (Neat combo.)-Quite a few missions.-Star Wars!!!And oddly enough thats where it ends. Cons--The lightsaber duels feel like they're *click click* and hope you hit your target. (edit) to me, combat feels rather simplistic, but, they do have some skill involved according to review comments.-The difficulty get artifically inflated as you play, with more enemies carrying sabers and using force powers, so you eventually have to save after each fight just so you don't get stuck playing the samething over and over again. -Saber duels are more based on luck rather then any skill, maybe you hit them, maybe you don't, maybe thay hit you and kill you. -Force powers are a drag, offensive ones don't work most of the time, but you can't defend yourself from them like your enemy can. You have to spend a force power upgrade point every mission, so once you get the once you want and need, you don't want the others and they just get in the way when selecting powers. Force powers are seperated into light and dark side powers and by your choices you can warrent at most comment on your choice. I hate this because it's said early in the game that "Force powers themselves aren't good or evil, but it's the user." So why the #*%4 can't I use force lightning without being judged.-Blasters become useless in the later game as force users and Boba Fett(why?) just side step your shots, litteraly.-Missions don't really flow with the story, which isn't one of the better ones at that.Personal thoughs-This game feels more like a "what could have been" tittle. It makes you want a good Star Wars RPG like Knights of the Old Republic mixed with some of the combat stylings of this game. It's a game that starts out good, then it leaves an after taste, and finally you just end up feeling bad. Sort of like cheap booze.Do I regret buying the game, no, but it is a game that could be done better. the worst part about it is that you end up wanting something better, and you look at the game wanting to improve it.Side note-"only siths deal in absolutes." Steams rating system is "yes" or "no". Think about that for a second.My review is based on personal feelings and experiance. I would rate this game 7/10, though to me this game doesn't feel as good as others make it out to be. Again, thats my oppinion.

content:
y 21, 2016
												Honestly, I didn't expect to enjoy Jedi Academy as much as I did. Like with Jedi Outcast, I simply don't think it lives up to the quality of Dark Forces 1 or 2.This is not to say the game is bad. Jedi Academy is definitely an improvement compared to (Dark Forces 3) Jedi Knight 2: Jedi Outcast for Raven Software, but I can't help but wonder if the game is simply too shallow for me to enjoy.The multiplayer, however, I can see as being enjoyable if I had friends to enjoy that content, so if you want the best Jedi Knight multiplayer community and mod-support, then this is definitely your game.The Star Wars Fan-Fiction SimulatorI say this with all good intentions. Ironically, as I found Outcast's reliance on the lore my main gripe, the reliance on the lore is what makes Jedi Academy entertaining.You choose a template of characters, outfits and lightsabers--for some reason each alien species is set for one gender--and revist locations of the movies. You'll fight alongside heroes like Chewbacca, Kyle Katarn, Luke Skywalker. You'll fight against the snow Yeti's from Hoth, Boba Fett and the Sith Apprentice from Outcast. While I hate how the series has become more fan-service than creating original characters and stories, I can't deny there is something to enjoy in buddying up with your favorite hero. To make up for the lack in creativity, the level design (and variety) are what makes this change bearable.Not only will you have a more colorful variety of locals, but the mission-structures have changed, some for the better and some for the worse. Missions that have you exploring for a secret base while lost in the tundra winds of Hoth or scavenging for pieces of tech while avoding the sands of a worm-infested desert are a nice change of pace.What doesn't work are the racerbike mission, the Rancor "Stealth" mission, and the other side-operations where the gameplay doesn't feel like it was polished enough to be fun. Relying on the allies' AI to act properly is a terrible idea because there's no command system to tell them what to do (like running away while I distract a Rancor), and I think some gameplay changes (the rancerbike jousting mission) have broken controls. Thankfully, the game doesn't require you to play every single level, and you can always back out to choose something else. So instead of a completely polished, excellent campaign we get probably 3/4ths of good ideas, and the rest that are meh at best, which helps to mitigate the tediousness of the lightsaber combat.Supposedly the Best Lightsaber Combat Ever?Maybe I don't understand the lightsaber mechanics, but I fail to see what makes JA's mechanics the best. It's exactly the same basic mechanics from Jedi Knight 1 & 2: Hold LMB to attack, RMB to do a special/light-saber throw. However, they added in combo-based moves to the fighting system that feel as demanding as a fighting game. The best I can say about this new system is that there is a great sense of fluidity in the animations. Jumping off of walls, doing cartwheel attacks, power-strikes or crouch attacks, and evading a down-ward stab by rolling away go to make the combat feel the most lively. Weapon styles and attack strategies are also added to give you more options in combat.All of this, I agree, makes the combat feel so great.The drawback to this combo system is that you have to rely memorizing the moves, and when you are trying to use them it can feel too rigid to get down properly. But maybe that's just a skill-barrier I haven't mastered yet; it's not the reason why I find this combat system shallow.The reason why I'm not engaged in Jedi battles is that I cannot read my enemies' moves or know, for certain, whether I'll land a blow or not. I've had better luck winning battles if I flail around and hold the attack button then try to land precise strikes, either with one-handed light-sabers or with two of them.Maybe the combat is balanced for multiplayer only. Towards the end of the campaign where the game litters you with Dark Jedi, I never felt the combat system was refined enough to make me feel like I earned each victory. I preferred cleaving through the hordes of Stormtroppers, Droids or Smugglers because my Force abilities and my arsenal would be more useful. (Seriously, Jedi can reflect rockets?)Why Is Jedi Academy OK but Not Great, and Why Is Jedi Knight 2: Outcast Bad?For one, the level design and the lightsaber mechanics are much more refined than Outcast ever hoped to be. Another reason, as mentioned before, the game will vary up your playstyle either by fighting new enemies or making new mission  types that change up your arsenal to not make you grow bored of the lightsaber combat.That last part is what Outcast failed to remember when it made lightsabers the most efficent weapon to use to protect yourself and to mow down your enemies. When fighting the giant Dark Stromtroppers with rockets/concusion rifles, it's best to attack them with heavy weaponry from afar than charge in with Protect enabled.Also, by giving you the lightsaber from the get-go, you now have the Force abilities from the start to make up for relying on the light-saber so much in Outcast. The only thing I don't think Raven Software got right is making a better story. It's so obvious what happens from the first few cutscenes that the "suspsense" is laughable. The canon characters were the only bits that felt as interesting as Outcast.Unfortunately, the story is not the only disappointing feature of Jedi Academy. For whatever reason, you won't unlock a second saber style until the first round of missions are done, and then you won't unlock a new lightsaber type until you get to the final 4/5 missions. There is no New Game Plus mode to make replaying the game entertaining, not unless you enable cheats which can break the game if Force points aren't allocated properly.This is such a majorly missed opportunity where the game could've focused more on how the three combat styles (one-handed, two one-handed, two-sided) relied on different tactics when fighting enemies throughout the campaign. (I've heard some argue it was for balance reasons but I don't see why that couldn't be an option.)Even then, I still don't think the quality of Jedi Academy, even at its greatest and ignoring its worse aspects, ever reaches the peak of Dark Forces 1/2. (Something I've gone into great detail in my Jedi Knight 2 Steam review.)The only reason I'm complaining about the assocation of the games is because I have expectations from the previous games that haven't been reached.A Bitter End for a Promising New BeginningDespite everything I've gone through with Outcast and the worst parts of Jedi Academy, I would still like this series to be given another chance.I'd love for Raven Software, or another company, to try the Dark Forces/Jedi Knight format (or even make a Jedi Academy sequel forgoing everything) one more time because I think what they achieved here is a step in the right direction. Something along the lines of Witcher 1's weapon styles, added into Dark Souls/Risen 1/Spectacle-Fighter gameplay, and given the Star Wars treatment would be a beautiful game to play. And because of the longevity of this title by its fans is still strong I think there is more than enough of an audience who would be willing for another game.

content:
y 13, 2014
												This game is a classic, one of the best Star Wars games ever made.You play as Jaden Korr starting off as a Jedi Padawan and as you play through the game you become a Jedi Knight or Master, the game is based along the same storyline as the Dark Forces games and like the Dark Forces games it's based after the Galactic Civil War between the Rebelion and the Galactic (Sith) Empire of course if you've seen the movies you'll know the Rebels win and they form The New Republic, because of how few Jedi are left and there are even less Jedi Masters some students were asigned more than one master, Jaden and another Jedi Padawan Rosh Penin under the jedi master Kyle Katarn.The story says you are a Human Male but you can chose to be a Kel Dor male, a Rodian Male, a Female Human, Twi'lek and Zabrak changing your race doesn't change how you sound, you will always have one of two voices, aswell as that you can customize your lightsaber, this game has the second best or the best lightsaber customization to Star Wars Galaxies, again the story says Jaden has a purple lightsaber but you can change the colour if you want, but in singleplayer he can't have a red lightsaber, you can also choose from a few handles for each saber, one is the saber Anikan uses and another is the one Obi Wan uses, aswell as a single saber you can use duel sabers and a saber stalf saber stalfs have their own unique handles too, chosing duel sabers or a saber stalf over a single saber does seem cool but the single sabers are more flexible with three attack modes, light medium and heavy each with their strengths and weaknesses.The story of the Dark Forces games is probably one giant "What If" scenario, what if Anakin didn't wipe out all the Jedi in the temple what if he missed a few and they escaped? even though irionically his son Luke, (with the help of his badass buddy Kyle Katarn) trains these people to (most likely) become amazing jedi. Like most to all jedi-themed classic Star Wars games you can chose to be good or bad, i will not explain in this review for spoiler reasons how to chose your side and how it will end.Multiplayer is very much like Quake 3 only with three types of grenades, the ability to use the force and customize your lightsaber and of course you can chose a red blade.Like Quake 3 you can chose from a large nomber of characters from the Dark Forces games even people you don't see in Jedi Academy aswell as your own characters, the character creation is exactly the same as in singleplayer.You can chose to be focused arround dark side powers or light side powers not both, each side has their own unique team power in the team-based games, some powers act differently to how they do in singleplayer and you can have power "loadouts" making it easier to change power builds.There are six game modes, Deathmatch, TDM, Duel, Power Duel, Capture the Flag and a class based Siege gamemode.Deathmatch and TDM are basically the same as always, your cloths and saber is coloured based on what team you are on and in TDM you can chose to have it light powers vs dark powers, the first team to hit the score limit or the team with the most score when the time runs out wins.Duel is also very self explanatory, a good old 1-on-1 battle Power Duel is 2-on-1 but the person by himself gets a few advantiges to even things out, you can chose to have weapons or go lightsaber only, lightsaber only is probably the best choice for duels since there aren't any weapons or powerups inside the arena, the person who hits the win limit or has the most wins... well wins.Capture the flag is what it always has been, if you've played Quake 2, 3, any Untral Torunament or Metal Techs 4 through to 7 (the Tribes games) you'll know what it is, like all team gmaes in Jedi Academy and most team-based games/gamemodes there are two teams.In Siege there is an attacking team and a defending team. The attackers have to make their way through the base and the defenders have to stop this, i havn't played much of siege persenally but i know that it has vehicles and it's class based with no AI, vehicles and mounted guns.Also you don't have to have a lightsaber in Multiplayer for those who want a little bit of an extra chalange, and play agenst players since the AI aren't that smart even on the Jedi Master difficulty.If your Star Wars dream was to become a Jedi i hightly reccomend this game aswell as that it's an awesome game in general, there aren't many Star Wars gems like this anymore since EA owns the rights to the Star Wars games so we must enjoy the few we have left.

content:
1, 2016
 Short Review: Pros:- Not too bad Graphics- Amazing Storyline- Force Combat!- Backflips- Awesome community- No DLCS!Cons:- Poor Hit Detection- You need to install a multiplayer mod- Jedi Academy Multiplayer is dead- Lightsaber combat can be found difficult- Lack of Servers- Poor Map Design- Some Unbalanced LightSabers (Dual, Double-Sided,Standard)Full Review:STAR WARS™ Jedi Knight - Jedi Academy™ . Take on the role of a new student eager to learn the ways of the Force from Jedi Master Luke Skywalker. Interact with famous Star Wars characters in many classic Star Wars locations as you face the ultimate choice: fight for good and freedom on the light side or follow the path of power and evil to the dark side. This is a singleplayer or multiplayer based game. The multiplayer is most popular due to the lack of people bothering with the story line. I mostly use Multiplayer so my review will take place in the Multiplayer.  Combat against other players and AI. The Combat system on the most popular mod, MBII ( Movie Battles 2) is amazing. It has everything to offer as well as playing with a real person instead of a coded character. If you are a Padawan and not ready to be a jedi nor a jedi master, I suggest you play on Multiplayer and make a private match, NOT USING MBII but instead Evolution of Combat 3. All the download links to the mod will be at the end of the review. In EOC3, You can launch a .bat file from the downloaded folder in your Steamapps (C:\Program Files (x86)\Steam\steamapps\common\Jedi Academy\GameData\GameData\Evolution_of_Combat_III>)and you can choose which one.  Evolution of Combat III:  In this mod, You can spawn any NPC, change maps, change saber and change your class to jedi master as well as playing god. You can spawn in Chewbacca and make him fight Darth Vader. Or you could spawn in Luke Skywalker and make him fight against a sith lord. It's all up to you how you play god. MovieBattles 2 FACT: Did you know that on the majority on servers, they have Fin and Kylo Ren? Including Kylo Ren's Lightsaber! About The Review: I will mark this review as positive and will return in the near future to the mod page to see what other mods they have made. Last time i heard, there will be a Rogue One Mod with EVERYTHING in it at the end of the year. Maybe i might add more to this review. Thank You:http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=707978816 If you found this review helpful don’t forget to give it a thumbs up also check out my other reviews and let me know what you thought by leaving a comment. If you like you can add me on steam and we can play games like CS:GO, Minecraft etc. Also dont forget to rate my games and let me know what you think of them!Mods:https://www.moviebattles.org - Movie Battles 2www.moddb.com/mods/evolution-of-combat-iv - EOC IVwww.moddb.com/mods/serenitysabersystems - EOC III
